Articles.Content: We all know that throught the years NASA and ESA have collaborated with KSP. So why doesn't KSP collaborate with RosCosmos or InterKosmos? Maybe make it as a last DLC? That would be mad cool.

Simple answer

YES
 

Maybe with some Angara parts as well as improved soyuz

On 2/20/2022 at 6:14 AM, BuranAce said:

Simple answer

YES
 

Maybe with some Angara parts as well as improved soyuz

Proton parts too

Some content has been removed.

A gentle reminder, please avoid political topics. Politics are not allowed in the KSP forums.

Thank you for your understanding.

I don't see it happening, even without current events. RosCosmos hasn't really done anything beyond low Earth orbit in its 31 years of existence, with two Mars-bound missions (Mars 96 and Fobos-Grunt) both failing in LEO and subsequently falling back to Earth; most of its efforts have gone into the ISS and joint projects with other agencies such as ESA and NASA. To put it bluntly, there's not much to add.

Making History has a good selection of Soviet-era rocket parts- Vostok/Voskhod pods and airlock, engines and boosters to make a passable replica of the R-7 (and all the derivatives that use the same basic layout even now, 65 years after it first launched Sputnik 1 into orbit!)- plus the stock Stayputnik which is an obvious Sputnik 1 reference and even one of the four starter Kerbals, named after Soviet cosmonaut Valentina Tereshkova.

Spoiler

If you have Making History and want some more parts to add to the Soviet stuff, I recommend KeR-7 which covers most of the basics- upper stage engines, service modules for the pods, a proper core tank for the R-7 style rockets and other goodies; if you're more into probes, ProbesPlus has a few good ones with Kerbalised versions of various spacecraft including Venera orbiters and landers and the Fregat upper stage; and there are plenty of true-to-life replica mods out there for probes, spacecraft and rockets if that's what you want.

Well, I'm playing on Enhanced Edition, so...

plus the stock Stayputnik which is an obvious Sputnik 1 reference

stayputnik is the american vanguard

Stayputnik - Wikipedia

Quote

Newspapers in the United States published prominent headlines and articles describing the failure with plays on the name of the Russian satellite, Sputnik, such as "Flopnik",[9] "Kaputnik",[10] "Oopsnik", "Dudnick" and "Stayputnik".
I highly doubt a collaboration with Roscosmos is coming due to both politics and the fact that with ksp2 so close a doubt that will release anything else
